metadata.titleEn: China downscaled CMIP6 precipitation, temperature and wind speed dataset (1979-2100)
metadata.description:
China 0.25 ° precipitation, the maximum temperature, minimum temperature and near-surface wind speed forcing datasets, originally from six CMIP6 models (CanESM5, FGOALS-g3, GFDL-CM4, IPSL-CM6A-LR, MPI-ESM1-2-HR and MRI-ESM2-0), use the China meteorological forcing dataset (CMFD)'s gridded precipitation and temperature as the observed reference, after bilinear interpolated to spatial resolution of 0.25 °, the daily precipitation, the maximum temperature and minimum temperature of the six models are downscaled and bias-corrected based on the equidistant cumulative distribution function method. Its start from 1979 to 2014 in the historical period, and from 2015 to 2100 under two future scenarios, which are SSP2-RCP4.5 and SSP5-RCP8.5 respectively. 
After statistical downscaling, the mean absolute error of models' monthly precipitation, the maximum temperature and minimum temperature all have substantial declines, and the correlations with observed values are closed to 1. Forcing the variable infiltration capacity (VIC) hydrological model can get applicable runoff simulation results, it can be useful for China future climate analysis and watershed hydrological projection research.
metadata.instructions:
File name: data stored in .nc format, the file name "XX_vars_models_periods_yyyy", in which XX (BC or DS) represent the processing method, the BC representative downscaling bias-correction, DS represent only resampling to 0.25°, “vars“ represent variables, "models" represent patterns, "periods" represent the period, "yyyy" represent the year, such as "BC_PREC_CanESM5_historical_1979" represents the .nc file describes statistically downscaled CanESM5 model's daily precipitation in China in historical period from January 1, 1979 to December 31, 1979.
Method to read data: all files can use the "ncdump" command to read detail information, and can also read them with MATLAB, Python, cdo or nco tool, besides, these files not only include the corresponding variable, but also has the latitude and longitude variable. If you want to view the file in the form of picture, you can use the ArcGIS to open it.

literatureList.titleEn: Estimation of future runoff in China based on CMIP6 mid-to-high temperature rise scenarios.

background: The Sixth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC AR6) indicates that the Earth’s mean temperature has increased by 1.1°C relative to the preindustrial revolution period of 1850–1900 and that the rate of increase in global surface temperature in the period of 1970–2020 is greater than that in any 50-year period prior to 2000. Large amounts of greenhouse gases emitted by human activities are a primary cause of global warming (IPCC, 2021); furthermore, elevated CO2 concentrations cause plant stomata to close, leading to reduced transpiration and thus affecting river flows (Gedney et al., 2006). Studies have shown (Skliris et al., 2016) that a 1°C increase will affect the hydrological cycle, amplifying the ambient humidity at a rate of 3–4%. Global climate models (GCMs) can describe in detail the changes in atmospheric motion, heat exchange, and sea-land-air-ice interactions over time (Gleick, 1989) and are effective tools for studying the effects of historical, present, and future atmospheric changes on surface physical processes (Gonzalez et al., 2010; Sun et al., 2013; Guo et al., 2015). Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) has improved the simulation of temperature and precipitation in the China region compared with Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 (CMIP5) (Jiang et al., 2020); specifically, the dry bias is significantly reduced in southern China (Zhu et al., 2020). CMIP6 is based on the Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) of CMIP5 (van Vuuren et al., 2011) and proposes the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) (Riahi et al., 2017), which can reflect newer and more diverse greenhouse gas concentration changes under social development (O’Neill et al., 2016). However, the spatial resolution of GCMs is coarse, and downscaling bias correction is usually required for finer-resolution basin-scale hydrological model simulations, where statistical downscaling is more widely used than dynamical downscaling due to simpler calculations and more reliable results (Ahmed et al., 2013).

The downscaling methods of GCMs mainly include dynamic downscaling and statistical downscaling. Although the former has clear physical meaning, it is more computationally intensive, while the latter is relatively easy to calculate and can correct the statistical bias of the GCMs with better results, so it is widely used in research regarding the impact of climate change at the regional scale (Sun et al., 2013; Zhang et al., 2016; Xu and Wang, 2019). Teutschbein and Seibert (2012) used different statistical methods to correct the precipitation and temperature of regional climate models for five mesoscale basins in Switzerland and found that the method based on the cumulative distribution function (CDF) was the most effective. Based on this result, Li et al. (2010) proposed the equidistant cumulative distribution function method (EDCDFm), which corrects the CDF of the GCM variables to be consistent with the measured data in the historical period, and the GCM output of the future scenario is corrected according to the difference between the CDF of the GCMs historical period and the measured data. The study shows that EDCDFm can effectively capture the extreme values of climate elements and improve the accuracy of the GCMs and model simulation after downscaling.

Generally, a value of NSE closer to 1 indicates that the simulation results are better, and an NSE less than 0 indicates that the simulation results are unreliable. The NSE of monthly streamflow between simulations and observations is at or above 0.60 at each station (Table 2), suggesting that the VIC model is more applicable to hydrological simulations in China.
research objective: In this paper, we use the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) to perform downscaling and bias correction in daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for six CMIP6 models based on the historical gridded data from the high-resolution China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD). We use the bias-corrected precipitation, temperature, and daily mean wind speed to drive the variable infiltration capacity (VIC) hydrological model, and study the changes in multiyear average annual precipitation, annual evapotranspiration and total annual runoff depth relative to the historical baseline period (1985–2014) for the Chinese mainland, basins and grid scales in the 21st century future under the SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios.

This study, based on the VIC hydrological model, uses six CMIP6 GCMs (CanESM5, FGOALS-g3, GFDL-CM4, IPSL-CM6A-LR, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, and MRI-ESM2-0) data with EDCDFm statistical downscaling bias-corrected and two future scenarios, SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5, to project future changes in the terrestrial surface water cycle in the Chinese mainland and major basins in the 21st century, using CMFD gridded data as a historical reference.
methods: In this paper, we use the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) to perform downscaling and bias correction in daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for six CMIP6 models based on the historical gridded data from the high-resolution China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD). We use the bias-corrected precipitation, temperature, and daily mean wind speed to drive the variable infiltration capacity (VIC) hydrological model, and study the changes in multiyear average annual precipitation, annual evapotranspiration and total annual runoff depth relative to the historical baseline period (1985–2014) for the Chinese mainland, basins and grid scales in the 21st century future under the SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios.

Therefore, this study used the EDCDFm method, CMFD and the six GCMs, which were first downscaled (DS) to 0.25° spatial resolution by bilinear interpolation; the daily Tmax, daily Tmax, and daily P of each GCM grid were then biased corrected (BC) based on the CDF of the corresponding grid series. The CDF was calculated by referring to the paper (Watterson, 2008; Li et al., 2010), where the probability density function (PDF) of temperature was estimated using a four-parameter beta function, the PDF of precipitation was estimated using a mixed gamma distribution function, and the parameters were estimated using the 1979–2014 series for the historical period and the 2015–2100 series for the future period. Three indicators were used to evaluate the downscaling bias-corrected GCMs data accuracy in monthly values: mean absolute error (MAE), root mean squared error (RMSE), and Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC).
dataset: The CMFD dataset spans 1979–2018 and includes seven elements: near-surface air temperature, surface pressure, specific humidity, wind speed, downward shortwave radiation, downward longwave radiation and precipitation rate, with a temporal resolution of 3 h and a spatial resolution of 0.1°. The daily precipitation rate, daily near-surface maximum temperature, daily near-surface minimum temperature, and daily near-surface wind speed of CMFD in 1979–2014 were interpolated to 0.25° by the bilinear interpolation method and as the measured information for the VIC model atmospheric drive and GCM bias correction.

Measured streamflow was used as references to evaluate the monthly simulation performance of the VIC and CaMa-Flood model; these measurements represented 15 hydrological stations in ten major river basins of China based on data from the Ministry of Water Resources and the Yingluoxia hydrological station (Figure 1 and Table 2) in the Hei Basin based on data from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (Liu et al., 2016a, 2016b; Xie, 2016).
findings: The study shows that the VIC model accurately simulates runoff in major Chinese basins; the model data accuracy improves substantially after downscaling bias correction; and the future multimodel-mean multiyear average annual precipitation, annual evapotranspiration, and total annual runoff depth for the Chinese mainland and each basin increase relative to the historical period in near future (2020–2049) and far future (2070–2099) under the SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios.

In summary, the hydrological station monthly streamflow based on CMFD and VIC model simulations had small errors and strong correlations with the observation streamflow in all basins, and the VIC model and CMFD driver used in this study performed well in the Chinese mainland (Table 2).

The monthly streamflow simulated by the CMFD-driven VIC model and CaMa-Flood model has NSEs of 0.6 in the YR and Huai basins and NSEs of 0.7–0.9 in other study basins, indicating that the VIC model hydrological simulation is applicable in the Chinese mainland. The hydrological projections of the single GCM data at the basin scale have large uncertainties. The multi-GCM arithmetic ensemble mean reduces the uncertainty of GCM projections. Under the SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios, the future water resources in the Chinese mainland and each basin are likely to increase, and the decrease in annual runoff is likely to occur mainly in the northwest and southwest regions, which can provide a strong scientific reference for future water resource management and risk analysis in China under climate change.

Verification.Question: Is the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) used to perform downscaling and bias correction for CMIP6 models?
Is the bilinear interpolation method used to interpolate daily meteorological data to a 0.25° grid resolution?
Does the VIC hydrological model use bias-corrected precipitation, temperature, and wind speed data for simulation in the Chinese mainland?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the downscaling of GCMs mainly performed using statistical methods like EDCDFm, dynamic methods, or a combination of both?

Concept Completion.Question: Where is the data for bias correction of climate models typically sourced from in studies focusing on China's climate?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to refine the spatial resolution of climate models for hydrological simulations in regional studies?
Example.Answer: The Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) is used to perform downscaling and bias correction in daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for six CMIP6 models, improving the spatial resolution for hydrological simulations.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset utilized to drive hydrological models and perform climate change impact studies in China?
Example.Answer: The China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD) is an example, as it provides historical gridded data used as a reference for driving hydrological models like the VIC model and performing climate change impact studies.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) used for bias correction and downscaling in climate models?
Feature Specification.Answer: corrects the cumulative distribution function, aligns with historical measured data, four-parameter beta function for temperature, mixed gamma distribution for precipitation, improves accuracy, captures extreme values

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes of the China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD) that make it suitable as a historical reference for climate studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: spans from 1979 to 2018, seven elements, near-surface air temperature, precipitation rate, high temporal resolution of 3 hours, spatial resolution of 0.1°

Quantification.Question: How many hydrological stations were used as references to evaluate the monthly simulation performance of the hydrological model?
What is the temporal resolution of the historical gridded data used for bias correction in the downscaling method?

Definition.Question: What is the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) in the context of bias correction for climate models?
Definition.Answer: The Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) is a statistical technique used to correct the bias of global climate models (GCMs) by adjusting the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of GCM variables to align with observed data during a historical period. It involves correcting the GCM output for future scenarios based on the difference between the CDF of GCMs during the historical period and the measured data, effectively capturing extreme climate values and improving the accuracy of downscaled model simulations.

Comparison.Question: How does the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) used for downscaling and bias correction compare to other statistical downscaling methods in terms of computational efficiency and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: The Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) is highlighted as being effective for downscaling and bias correction due to its ability to capture extreme values of climate elements and improve the accuracy of GCMs after downscaling. It is relatively easy to calculate compared to dynamic downscaling, making it efficient and reliable for regional-scale climate impact studies.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in data collection methods between the CMFD dataset and the measured streamflow data from hydrological stations in China?
Comparison.Answer: The CMFD dataset is based on high-resolution gridded data covering various atmospheric elements with a focus on a temporal resolution of 3 hours and spatial resolution of 0.1°. In contrast, the measured streamflow data from hydrological stations are point-based observations used to evaluate the monthly simulation performance of hydrological models, indicating a more localized and specific data collection approach.

Interpretation.Question: How do different statistical downscaling methods influence the observed patterns in climate model simulations, particularly in terms of temperature and precipitation?
Interpretation.Answer: Different statistical downscaling methods, such as the equidistant cumulative distribution function method (EDCDFm), influence climate model simulations by correcting the statistical biases in temperature and precipitation data. This correction aligns the model outputs more closely with observed data, potentially capturing extreme climate events more accurately and improving the correlation between simulated and observed values, as indicated by metrics like mean absolute error and Pearson correlation coefficient.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for statistical downscaling methods over dynamic downscaling when refining GCM data for regional climate studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Statistical downscaling is often preferred over dynamic downscaling because it is relatively easy to calculate and can correct the statistical bias of GCMs with better results. This approach is widely used due to its simpler calculations and more reliable outcomes in regional scale climate change impact studies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is bias correction necessary when using GCMs for hydrological modeling in regional climate studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Bias correction is necessary because the spatial resolution of GCMs is coarse and may not accurately represent finer-resolution basin-scale hydrological processes. Downscaling bias correction improves the accuracy of the GCMs, making the data more suitable for detailed hydrological simulations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors led to the development of the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method for downscaling climate data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method was developed based on findings that different statistical methods could effectively correct precipitation and temperature biases in regional climate models. The method corrects the cumulative distribution function of GCM variables to be consistent with measured historical data, improving the accuracy of climate element extremes and model simulations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences for hydrological model accuracy when using statistical downscaling methods like EDCDFm on global climate model outputs?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of statistical downscaling methods such as EDCDFm improves the accuracy of hydrological model simulations by significantly reducing bias in the GCM outputs. This is reflected in the increased correlation with observed data and enhanced model performance, indicating that downscaled datasets can provide more reliable inputs for hydrological projections.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in downscaling and bias-correcting global climate model data for regional climate analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) is used to perform downscaling and bias correction on daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for six CMIP6 models. This involves first downscaling the GCMs to a 0.25° spatial resolution using bilinear interpolation, followed by bias correction based on the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the corresponding grid series. The CDF is calculated using a four-parameter beta function for temperature and a mixed gamma distribution function for precipitation, with parameters estimated from historical data from 1979–2014 and future data from 2015–2100.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the CMFD dataset utilized in the process of improving hydrological model simulations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The CMFD dataset, which spans 1979–2018 and includes elements like near-surface air temperature and precipitation rate, is interpolated to a 0.25° resolution by bilinear interpolation to serve as the measured information for atmospheric drive and GCM bias correction in the VIC hydrological model. This improves the accuracy of hydrological simulations and facilitates the study of changes in precipitation, evapotranspiration, and runoff depth relative to historical baselines.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological steps are taken to evaluate the accuracy of downscaled and bias-corrected GCM data for hydrological simulations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy of downscaled and bias-corrected GCM data is evaluated using three indicators: mean absolute error (MAE), root mean squared error (RMSE), and Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC). These metrics are applied to assess the performance of the downscaling and bias correction in capturing monthly values, thus ensuring the data's reliability for driving the VIC hydrological model.

Enablement.Question: What statistical techniques enable the downscaling and bias correction of global climate model outputs for regional climate analysis?
Enablement.Answer: The Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) enables the downscaling and bias correction of daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for CMIP6 models using historical gridded data from the high-resolution China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD).

Enablement.Question: How does the use of gridded historical datasets enable more accurate hydrological modeling on a regional scale?
Enablement.Answer: The use of gridded historical datasets like the China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD) enables more accurate hydrological modeling by providing high-resolution reference data for bias correction of climate model outputs, which are then used to drive hydrological models like the Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) model.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do different greenhouse gas concentration scenarios enable projections of future climate impacts in regional studies?
Enablement.Answer: Different greenhouse gas concentration scenarios, such as SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5, enable projections of future climate impacts by providing varied pathways for social and economic development, which reflect changes in greenhouse gas concentrations and allow researchers to study potential future changes in the terrestrial surface water cycle in regional studies.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset require statistical downscaling and bias correction before being used in hydrological models?
Expectation.Answer: A dataset might require statistical downscaling and bias correction because global climate models (GCMs) often have coarse spatial resolution, which may not capture local climate variations accurately. Statistical downscaling and bias correction can adjust the GCM outputs to align better with observed data, improving the reliability of simulations for regional-scale hydrological models.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) for downscaling in climate change impact studies?
Expectation.Answer: The expected benefits of using EDCDFm for downscaling include effectively capturing the extreme values of climate elements and improving the accuracy of climate model simulations after downscaling. This method corrects the cumulative distribution function of the GCM variables to match observed historical data, leading to more reliable projections for future scenarios.

Judgmental.Question: How effective is the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) in improving the accuracy of climate model data through downscaling and bias correction?
Judgmental.Answer: The EDCDFm method is considered effective in improving the accuracy of climate model data, as it successfully captures extreme values and reduces statistical biases, leading to improved model simulations after downscaling. The study shows substantial improvements in data accuracy, with indicators such as mean absolute error and Pearson correlation coefficient demonstrating enhanced performance.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could future data collection methodologies be improved to enhance the reliability of hydrological projections using GCMs under different climate scenarios?
Judgmental.Answer: Future data collection methodologies could be improved by increasing spatial and temporal resolution, integrating more diverse sources of observational data, and implementing advanced statistical methods for bias correction. These enhancements could lead to more precise hydrological projections by better capturing local climate variability and reducing uncertainties in GCM outputs.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the VIC hydrological model is validated for accuracy in simulating runoff in Chinese basins.
Assertion.Answer: The VIC hydrological model's accuracy in simulating runoff is validated by comparing model simulations to measured streamflow data from 15 hydrological stations across ten major river basins in China. The model's performance is assessed using measures like the Nash-Sutcliffe Efficiency (NSE), which indicates a strong correlation between simulated and observed streamflows in these regions, suggesting its applicability for hydrological simulations in China.
